properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By Village Of Elbow
properties.Summary:
Description: Effective immediately, a Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Village of Elbow. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Village of Elbow water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2020-04-10T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-04-07T09:19:58-06:00, 5A908EF5-AB49-4BA5-FF76-0B7906F5F6FE
Area: Village of Elbow
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very windy conditions with snow and some rain Thursday night and Friday Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Total snowfall: 5 cm except 15 possible over Prince county. Time span: Thursday night into Friday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Thursday evening and then change to rain Friday morning. Very strong winds will also develop, with the highest gusts occurring Friday morning. Conditions will improve late Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-08T11:26:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-07T19:27:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3619727273.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very windy and wet and even some snow Thursday night and Friday Locations: Nova Scotia Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h except 90 along the coast. Water Levels: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected, likely exceeding high astronomical tide. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas along Digby and Yarmouth counties and along the South Shore. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total snowfall: Over northern Nova Scotia including Cape Breton, 5 cm except 10 or more over higher terrain. Time span: Thursday night into Friday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Thursday evening and then change to rain by Friday morning. The snow will persist until midday Friday over Cape Breton. Strong winds will also develop, with the highest gusts occurring over coastal areas. Conditions will improve late Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-08T11:19:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-07T19:20:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4249478928.2020
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Continued For The Red River Between Emerson And The Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Red River between Emerson and the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2020-04-08T11:45:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-04-07T11:58:16-05:00, BA7FC159-A538-3265-081A-C4A45B602094
Area: The Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winterlike storm to bring very windy conditions with snow and some rain Thursday night and Friday Maximum wind gusts: 100 km/h. Water Levels: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected, likely exceeding high astronomical tide. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Time span: Thursday night into Friday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Thursday evening and then change to rain Friday morning. Very strong winds will also develop, with the highest gusts occurring Friday morning. Conditions will improve late Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-08T11:04:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-07T19:05:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2703724229.2020
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winterlike storm to bring significant snow and wind. Locations: New Brunswick. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 80 km/h. Time span: Thursday through later Friday. Water Levels: Pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected, likely exceeding high astronomical tide. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas along the Fundy shore Thursday night, and along the Acadian coast and Bay of Chaleur on Friday. Remarks: Wet snow is expected to begin Thursday, but rates of accumulation will likely increase Thursday night as temperature slowly falls. The snow will likely change to rain over the Fundy region and southeastern portions of the province. Strong winds will also develop, with the highest gusts occurring over coastal areas. Conditions will improve late Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-08T11:10:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-07T19:11:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1126598386.2020
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system is moving through northern Manitoba today. Snow continues to accumulate in the far north late this morning, however at Thompson and Lynn Lake it has tapered off to light. Further accumulation of 5 to 10 cm are possible over far northern regions this afternoon as the snow shifts eastward towards Gillam, Shamattawa and Churchill. The system will also begin slowly weakening as it moves toward the Hudson Bay coast later today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-08T05:29:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-07T15:34:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1646667464.2020
Area: Brochet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A low pressure system will develop in the Gulf of Alaska later today and spread snow to the Haines Road and South Klondike highway tonight. The snow will intensify and strong south winds will develop on Wednesday as the low moves into southwest Yukon. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 25 cm are expected by Wednesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-08T05:10:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-07T13:11:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2745296575.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp, South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada
